titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Max Lerner Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:10

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, speeches, writings, and other papers, (including research and teaching materials, photographs, memorabilia, newspaper and periodical clippings, books, and radio and television tapes) of Max Lerner, an American educator, author, lecturer, historian, and political scientist. The papers focus on Lerner's public life and career with very little material on his personal or family life. The papers document Lerner's close association with Justice Felix Frankfurter and Harold J. Laski, his controversial writings on homosexuality, his work with the Democratic Party during Adlai Stevenson's presidential campaigns, his work on behalf of Jewish causes and Zionism, and his activities during the "red scare" of the 1950s.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Max Lerner, 1962, 1965, 1966, 1970, and 1981; gift of Richard Cummings, 1996; gift of Stephen Lerner, 1997 and 2004; gift of Robert Schmuhl, 2000, and 2010; purchase from Ardwright Chamberlain, 1999.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Max Lerner Papers (MS 322). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in four series and six accessions: I. Correspondence, 1935-1969. II. Speeches and Writings, 1927, 1932-1969. III. Photographs, Press Clippings and Memorabilia, 1955-1969. IV. Books in the Max Lerner Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers of Max Lerner in the Yale University Library are divided into four series and six additions: I. Correspondence; II. Speeches and Writing; and III. Photographs, Press Clippings, and Memorabilia. IV. Books in the Max Lerner Papers.

Series I, CORRESPONDENCE, has been divided into two sections. The first section contains Lerner's letters to and from important political, literary, and academic figures, and the publishers of his books. The collections begins in 1935 and continues until 1969. Harold J. Laski (approximately 120 letters) and Felix Frankfurter (approximately 350 letters) are probably the most important correspondents. Other major correspondents are Hugo L. Black (47 letters), Howard K. Beale (16 letters), Chester Bowles (21 letters), James M. Burns (21 letters), Hiram Haydn (75 letters), Bruce Bliven (100 letters), Eleanor Roosevelt (10 letters), Adlai Stevenson (8 letters), Arthur Schlesinger, Jr. (50 letters), and James Wechsler (35 letters). The letters deal entirely with Lerner's public life and career; no family or personal correspondence is in this collection.

The second section of correspondence contains letters from less prominent persons and from the general public. It is arranged in chronological order and runs from 1935 until 1969. Of particular interest are the letters from readers in response to Lerner's columns in the New York Post, especially in the early 1950s. Lerner wrote several columns on the activities of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and a lengthy series on the Kinsey Reports and related subjects. The series produced the greatest reader response of any of Lerner's columns.

Series II, SPEECHES AND WRITINGS, the largest series, has been divided into four sections. The first contains Lerner's newspaper columns. A few are from the New York Star, but the columns appearing in the New York Post from 1949 until 1969 are almost complete, and these columns provide a useful guide to the evolution of Lerner's thought over the twenty year period. Background notes and rough drafts are included with many of the columns.

The second section of this series contains some of Lerner's printed magazine articles and the background notes for them. This collection is far from complete, and the notes are in an extremely dilapidated state. Many of Lerner's articles, however, appeared in The New Republic in the 1940s and early 1950s; so interested persons should consult the indices of the magazine for those years.

The third section contains some of Lerner's speeches and the background notes for others. Again the notes are in extremely poor condition. In the 1940s and early 1950s when the widespread use of tape recorders madetranscriptionmuch easer, many of Lerner's public addresses were transcribed and printed. This section also contains some lecture notes for the courses that Lerner taught at Sarah Lawrence College in the 1930s.

The fourth section contains the notes, drafts, and proofs of Lerner's published books. Included in this section are the course outlines and syllabi from Brandeis University which formed the basis for America as a Civilization. Also in this section are the notes, drafts, and fragments of the books which Lerner did not complete or publish.

Series III, PHOTOGRAPHS, PRESS CLIPPINGS, AND MEMORABLILA, contains photographs, mostly unidentified, press clippings, book reviews, printed programs, and other memorabilia. These items have not been arranged in any particular order. The last box contains 47 tape recordings of radio and television programs in which Lerner participated in the 1950s and 1960s. (Transferred to Historical Sound Recordings)
Series IV, BOOKS IN THE MAX LERNER PAPERS, contains books authored or edited by Max Lerner.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Max Lerner was born in Minsk, Russia, in 1902 and came to the United States in 1907. His family lived first in New York City and then in New Haven, Connecticut, where he attended high school. Lerner received his B.A. degree from Yale University in 1923 and attended Yale Law School for one year. He received his M.A. degree from Washington University in 1925 and his Ph.D. from the Robert Brookings Graduate School of Economics and Government in 1927. He worked as assistant editor of the Encyclopedia of the Social Sciences and became managing editor. From 1932 until 1935 he taught political science at Sarah Lawrence College; he also taught at the Wellesley Summer Institute and the Harvard Summer School. From 1936 until 1938 he was editor of The Nation. In 1938 Lerner became professor of political science at Williams College, remaining there until 1943.

Throughout his career Lerner has been an active writer, commentator, and lecturer. From 1943 until 1948 he was editorial director of the newspaper PM and in 1948 and 1949 he was a columnist for its successor the New York Star. In 1949 Lerner became a regular columnist for the New York Post; his column appeared three times weekly for more than twenty years. Active in the founding of Brandeis University, Lerner became professor of American Civilization there in 1949 and remained there until his retirement. His well-known book, America as a Civilization, in large part grew out of his Brandeis course.

Lerner wrote many magazine articles and in the 1950s and 1960s spoke frequently before educational associations, college and university groups, religious and civic organizations, and on television and radio programs. He is the author of It is Later Than You Think (1938 rev. ed 1943), Ideas are Weapons (1939), Ideas for the Ice Age (1941), The Mind and Faith of Justice Holmes (1943), Public Journal (1945), The Portable Veblen (1948), Actions and Passions (1949), America as a Civilization (1957), The Unfinished Country (1959), The Essential Works of John Stuart Mill (1961), The Age of Overkill (1962), Education and a Radical Humanism (1962), and Tocqueville and American Civilization(1969).

Lerner married Anita Marburg in 1928, and they had three daughters: Constance, Pamela (dec.), and Joanna. They were divorced in 1940, and in 1941 he married Edna Albers; they had three sons: Michael, Stephen, and Adam. Max Lerner died mid 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: CORRESPONDENCE is divided into two sections. The first is arranged alphabetically by name of the writer and contains letters form important political, literary, and academic figures. The second section is arranged chronologically and contains letters from less prominent persons and from the general public. Copies of letters written by Max Lerner are filed under the name of the person to whom they were addressed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: SPEECHES AND WRITINGS are divided into five sections: newspaper columns, magazine articles, speeches and speech notes, books, and bibliographies. Items are filed chronologically within each section. The notes and draft for a particular column or book are filed with the final copy of the column or book.

scopecontent.p: Includes notes for 1958 columns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: PHOTOGRAPHS, PRESS CLIPPINGS, AND MEMORABILIA is divided into three sections: photographs, press clippings, and memorabilia. Within these sections, however, the items are filed in no particular order. The only exception is the last box containing tape recordings of some of Lerner's radio and television broadcasts which are filed chronologically; a list of these tapes is appended to this register.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence (.75 linear feet) is arranged chronologically; the bulk of it is from 1945 to 1969. It relates to Max Lerner's career in journalism and his writings. There is a large amount of correspondence with various publishers and editors, particularly Walter Minton at G. P. Putnam's Sons. Other letters concern Lerner's travels, speaking engagements, and participation in conferences and various media projects. Lerner also corresponded with many prominent writers, artists, politicians, and journalists on national and world politics and current events.

There are letters from the 1940s relating to Lerner's work on PM, and to and from his editor, Merle Thompson. In addition, there is correspondence on World War II; the Soviet Union; Edmund Wilson's attack on Stalin in 1946; Trotsky; post-war politics in France; anti-Semitism and Israel; the United Auto Workers; the Douglas nomination to the Supreme Court; the financial woes of Black Mountain College; and national and presidential politics. Items of particular interest include a copy of a 1945 letter from Senator Robert Taft on immigration restrictions and Jewish refugees, and letters from 1945 describing the liberation of a concentration camp in Germany and the writer's meeting with a Russian officer who was a great admirer of Lerner.

Correspondence from the 1950s documents Lerner's interest in national politics and homosexuality, and his work with several Jewish organizations. Prominent correspondents include Alfred C. Kinsey in 1954, criticizing Lerner's interpretation of his work; Langston Hughes in 1955, writing about his character "Simple;" and Edmund Wilson in 1956, discussing Rosenberg trial.

There are many letters from the 1960s concerning Lerner's work on television station WGBH's "Age of Overkill" series and his book by the same title. There are letters on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy; the Fanny Hill obscenity trial; Lerner's work on the New York Post ; and the war in Vietnam. Lerner's correspondence with Howard Zinn and Horace Bond in 1960, on African-American education in the South, and the Louis Malle in 1970, on a proposed film on utopian societies, is particularly interesting. Some of Lerner's writings are found in the 1960s correspondence, including a 1968 paper delivered at the American Medical Association, "Technology and Creativeness;" a 1969 speech delivered at the Texas Library Association; and a 1970 poem.
The correspondence also includes several undated notes and letters, chiefly from readers, including one on J. Edgar Hoover's alleged homosexuality.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings (3.75 linear ft.) are arranged in seven sections: articles and columns, book reviews, books, diaries, panels and symposia, research files, and television. Material is arranged alphabetically within each section. The series consists of notes, drafts, some manuscript copies, and typescripts of Max Lerner's published and unpublished writings, some transcripts of his participation in conferences and symposia, and his research files and working notes. There are also several diaries, including a "nine-month journal of adventures of ideas in Asia, the Middle East, and Europe;" diary entries on Lerner's trips to Rome and India; and diary descriptions of his dreams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lectures and speeches (1.0 linear feet) consist of Max Lerner's notes and drafts for speeches and talks, especially commencement addresses. They are arranged alphabetically within three sections: Institution/Organization, Location, and Subject. A fourth section, Other, is arranged alphabetically by type of material and contains programs and printed material from commencements, conferences, and lectures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Teaching materials (0.5 linear feet) are comprised of Lerner's outlines, lecture notes, and syllabi for courses taught at various institutions, particularly Brandeis University and the New School for Social Research. They are arranged alphabetically by name of institution. Within an institution, the files are arranged by course title or number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this accession pertain to Lerner's 1994 book, Nine Scorpions in a Bottle (originally titled Great Judges, Great Cases\). They are primarily drafts, but also include correspondence, clippings, and research materials.

did.unittitle: The Letters of Lincoln Steffen [annotated by Max Lerner]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accession also includes 2001-M-035.

The materials in these accessions are arranged in the following sections: correspondence, writings, teaching materials, personal, and research files and notes. An attempt has been made to maintain original order, but the accessions arrived at the repository in a random order. Some materials were contained in folders, others were not. Materials found in any given folder were kept together. When possible the handwritten titles or notes on the original folders have been used. Researchers should be advised that many folders include not only the material under which subject heading they appear, but also clippings, short writings, notes, research materials, contracts, fliers, and correspondence. Materials relating to each of Lerner's unpublished books have been placed together for ease of use.

Correspondence is divided into subject and chronological subsections. The subject correspondence is arranged alphabetically by the name of the writer or subject of the folder. Writings include diaries, books, a screenplay, short writings, columns and lectures. The diaries and columns are arranged in chronological order, while books and short writings are in alphabetical order by title. The teaching materials are organized alphabetically by school. Personal is arranged alphabetically by subject and includes articles about Lerner, reviews of Ted and the Kennedy Legend, materials concerning his hospitalization, publicity items from his lectures, and photographs. The research notes and files are materials that Lerner may have used in the preparation of his many writings. They arrived in no discernible order. Some were in labeled folders, others were not. One box contains what appear to be random jottings on thousands of loose pages of memo pads. The research value of these materials is unknown.

The greatest strengths of these two additions are handwritten diary entries primarily dating from the 1940s and 1988-1991, the last years of Lerner's life. The entries range in length from just a few lines to several pages. They detail Lerner's daily activities and contain his personal thoughts about his life and career. The materials from Lerner's untitled memoir, which include drafts, correspondence, and research notes, also contain reflections about his life and work, from his earliest childhood memories through his later years. The correspondence is of interest because of letters written by, or addressed, to a number of important persons from academia, politics, publishing, and other fields. The letters reflect Lerner's varied interests and multi-faceted career.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this accession are arranged in the following sections: writings by Max Lerner, writings about Max Lerner, and writings by others. When possible the handwritten titles or notes on the original folders have been used. Researchers should be advised that some folders include not only the material under which subject heading they appear, but also clippings, notes, research materials, and correspondence. Materials relating to each of Lerner's unpublished books, and the posthumously published The Wounded Titans , have been placed together for ease of use.
